questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of pain in his left hip. The pain started suddenly and has worsened over the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the thigh and is aggravated by movement. He had a fall while cycling around a month ago. He had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago that resolved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. There is no family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Flexing the hip causes external rotation and abduction. His leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and his erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management in orthopedics consists of protection, optimal loading, ice, compression, and elevation (POLICE principle), along with NSAIDs for analgesia. This patient has a stable SCFE because he can bear weight without crutches. Conservative management alone will not suffice because weight-bearing may lead to an unstable SCFE, which is associated with a high risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

B) INCORRECT:

The localization of pain and reduced range of motion indicates that this patient has a hip condition. A long cast alone is not useful to treat hip pathologies. A hip spica cast with a long leg cast may be used to immobilize the hip and prevent further slipping in patients with a stable SCFE. However, this treatment modality is associated with a higher rate of complications than the preferred treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotic therapy is indicated when septic arthritis is suspected, which also manifests with joint pain and restricted movement. However, a lack of fever, a normal ESR and leukocyte count, as well as pain for a period of 2 months make a diagnosis of septic arthritis unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Surgical pinning of the femoral head refers to the placement of 1–2 pins through the femoral neck into the epiphysis and is used to treat SCFE to prevent further slipping of the epiphysis and promote closure of the epiphyseal plate. Surgical pinning is indicated for both stable and unstable SCFE. Prior to surgery, patients should avoid weight-bearing.

E) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular injection of lidocaine is used to treat severe pain in the knee, hip, elbow, and shoulder joint, but it is not indicated to treat SCFE.

F) INCORRECT:

Proximal femoral osteotomy is used to surgically treat Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) in children > 8 years of age or those with advanced disease. LCPD manifests with hip pain and a decreased range of motion. However, LCPD most commonly affects children between the ages of 4 and 10 years, and the onset of symptoms is usually insidious, with hip pain gradually worsening over months. Additionally, the x-ray in LCPD is either unremarkable or shows a dense, proximal femoral epiphysis that has a thinned-out, irregular surface and subchondral lucencies (indicating subchondral fractures).
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a child

The left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.

This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.
questions.hint: This adolescent boy with obesity has left hip pain, a positive Drehmann sign (passive flexion causes external rotation and abduction), and x-ray findings (widening of the left hip joint, cranial displacement of the femoral neck in relation to the femoral head) suggestive of a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He has hypothyroidism. His only medication is levothyroxine. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears uncomfortable. He is at the 50th percentile for height and at the 95th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9,100/mm3



Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Serum



 TSH
3.6 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Septic arthritis of the left hip
Developmental dysplasia of the left hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has manifestations consistent with septic arthritis, such as joint pain and reduced range of motion, he is missing several key findings, such as fever, joint swelling, and abnormal lab values (e.g., increased ESR).

C) CORRECT:

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

E) INCORRECT:

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.

questions.text: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-week history of dull pain in the left hip. He is able to bear weight on the left hip but has severe pain when walking that has progressively worsened for the past 2 days. The pain does not radiate. He is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 95th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F). Physical examination shows restricted internal rotation and abduction of the left hip; the left groin is tender to palpation. When walking, he stands on his right leg for longer than his left leg, and he swings his left leg longer than his right leg. His leukocyte count is 7000/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 13 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Transient inflammation of the synovial membrane
Inadequate blood supply of the femoral head
Bacterial infection of the hip joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital dysplasia of the acetabulum causes developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). Although DDH manifests with hip instability, hip pain, restricted range of abduction, and difficulty walking, all of which are seen here, it typically becomes symptomatic in the first year of life, not in adolescence. In addition, this patient does not have any of the risk factors for DDH (e.g., female sex, breech presentation, family history of DDH) or leg length discrepancies.

B) INCORRECT:

Transient inflammation of the synovial membrane occurs in transient synovitis, which manifests with hip pain, antalgic gait, and restricted internal rotation, similar to what is seen here. However, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. In addition, the pain usually resolves within 14 days and would not persist for 4 weeks. Moreover, in transient synovitis, hip pain improves with abduction and most commonly affects younger children (3–8 years of age).

C) INCORRECT:

Inadequate blood supply of the femoral head is the underlying cause of avascular necrosis, which occurs in Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD). LCPD often manifests with insidious onset of hip pain, restricted range of motion, and antalgic gait without systemic inflammation (e.g., afebrile, normal leukocyte count, normal erythrocyte sedimentation rate). However, LCPD more commonly affects younger children (4–10 years of age), and obesity is not a risk factor. Moreover, patients with LCPD typically have pain that worsens with external rather than internal rotation.

D) CORRECT:

Proximal femoral growth plate instability is the underlying cause of SCFE. Although the mechanism remains unclear, SCFE usually affects boys aged 10–16 years of age with obesity. Severe pain and antalgic gait usually develop over weeks to months but can manifest suddenly after minor traumas or falls. A hip radiograph would show a widened femoral epiphyseal plate and/or femoral head posteromedial displacement in relation to the femoral neck. SCFE is treated with urgent surgical internal fixation with pinning of the femoral head.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of the hip joint causes septic arthritis. Although septic arthritis can manifest with joint pain and restricted range of motion, which are both seen here, patients usually present with fever, leukocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Moreover, hip pain from septic arthritis develops progressively in hours to days, not weeks.
questions.hint: Severe acute-on-chronic hip pain, restricted internal rotation and abduction, and an antalgic gait (i.e., shortened stance phase and increased swing phase of the affected leg) in a boy with obesity are consistent with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of right knee and thigh pain since starting basketball at his school 4 months ago. The pain worsens following basketball practice and games. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is 140 cm (4 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 43 kg (95 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/76 mm Hg. Physical examination in the supine position shows that the right knee is mildly flexed and the right leg externally rotated. There is no pain or restriction of the passive range of motion in the right knee but the patient resists passive extension and internal rotation of the hip joint. Palpation of the right knee and right hip does not show tenderness, swelling, or crepitus. There is no endpoint laxity when the tibia is pulled forward. Dorsalis pedis pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. The results of a complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within reference ranges. An x-ray of the right knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An MRI can be obtained after a negative knee x-ray if there is still a concern for internal derangement (e.g., knee effusion secondary to a bone, cartilage, ligamentous, meniscus, or patellar injury), infection, or malignancy. This patient, however, despite knee pain, has a normal range of motion of the right knee without point tenderness, anterior laxity, edema, or other signs and symptoms that suggest knee pathology. Therefore, an MRI of the knee is not the most appropriate next step in management.

B) CORRECT:

In patients presenting with nonspecific knee pain and no findings to suggest knee pathology, hip pathology must be considered as a potential source of knee pain, especially in pediatric patients. In pediatric patients like this one, with limited extension and internal rotation of the hip joint, an x-ray of the hip must be promptly obtained to rule out slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), which requires immediate avoidance of weight-bearing and urgent surgical intervention. If the x-ray of the hip shows no findings to suggest SCFE (e.g., widening of the joint space, displacement of the femoral head posteriorly and inferiorly to the femoral neck), Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease must be considered because patients with this condition commonly have normal radiographs in the early course of the disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Rest and ibuprofen therapy may be considered as supportive care for pain. However, in a patient with suspected referred pain, additional workup is indicated to exclude other conditions that might require urgent intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

An x-ray of the lumbar spine can be considered if referred back pain is suspected. Referred back pain can be caused by L2–L5 and S1 radiculopathies, which can manifest with thigh and knee pain, similar to what is seen in this patient. However, radiculopathies are uncommon in children, and patients typically also present with back pain, which is not seen here. Patients with radiculopathies may also present with weakness of knee extension, hip flexion and adduction, and reduced patellar reflex, none of which this patient has.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy of the knee is most commonly indicated in patients with acute knee injuries, such as osteochondral fractures, meniscal lesions, and ligamentous tears. This patient, however, despite knee pain, has a normal range of motion of the right knee without point tenderness, anterior laxity, edema, or other signs and symptoms that suggest knee pathology. Therefore, arthroscopy of the knee is not the most appropriate next step in management.
questions.hint: This patient's history of chronic, nonspecific knee and thigh pain in combination with a normal knee examination and imaging findings suggests referred pain.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with obesity reports one week of pain in his left knee, thigh, groin, and hip. He recently increased his exercise level to lose weight and become healthier, but there was no specific inciting event. His symptoms improve when he sits in a chair, left leg crossed over the right.
On physical examination, he demonstrates obligatory external rotation and abduction of the lower extremity with passive hip flexion and diminished, painful internal rotation of the hip.
On a hip radiograph, a virtual line drawn along the superior border of the femoral neck does not pass through the femoral head.
Which one of the following physical examination findings is this patient most likely to have?

choices.text: Positioning of the hip by the patient in slight internal rotation
Swelling and erythema over the hip joint
Palpable mass anterior to the hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

SCFE leads to a diminished range of motion at the hip. There is obligatory external rotation of the lower extremity during passive flexion of the hip. For this reason, patients prefer to sit in a chair with the affected leg crossed over the unaffected leg. There is also loss of internal rotation, abduction, and flexion of the hip.

B) CORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is an uncommon pediatric condition that must be diagnosed accurately and treated immediately. It is a type of instability of the proximal growth plate resulting from a Salter-Harris-type physeal fracture.

The most common manifestation of SCFE is unilateral groin and thigh pain, but the child may also report pain of the hip, knee, or both. Abnormal gait is also a common finding. SCFE leads to a diminished range of motion at the hip. There is obligatory external rotation of the lower extremity during passive flexion of the hip. For this reason, patients prefer to sit in a chair with the affected leg crossed over the unaffected leg. There is also loss of internal rotation, abduction, and flexion of the hip. Thigh atrophy may be present.

SCFE occurs predominantly in children age 10 to 14 years, at an average age of 13.5 years in boys and 12.0 years in girls (associated with puberty). It is more common in boys than girls (3:2 ratio). Obesity is the greatest risk factor for SCFE. It may be associated with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism, osteodystrophy of chronic renal failure, or growth-hormone treatment. About 20% of patients with SCFE have bilateral involvement at presentation, and an additional 20% to 40% progress to bilateral involvement, usually within 18 months.

Radiography of a patient with SCFE typically shows an epiphysis that stays in the acetabulum, while the neck displaces anteriorly and externally rotates (epiphysis posterior). A Klein line is drawn along the superior border of the femoral neck and usually passes through the femoral head. SCFE can be diagnosed if the superior border of the femoral neck does not pass through the femoral head.

Prevention of complications, such as avascular necrosis, is the goal of treatment for SCFE. The primary treatment is operative fixation.

Key learning point: In a 12-year-old boy with obesity, obligatory external rotation and abduction of the lower extremity with passive hip flexion and diminished, painful internal rotation are most consistent with a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis and hips (A: frog leg lateral view; B: AP view)

The right femoral epiphysis (yellow overlay) is displaced posteriorly and rotated medially on the femoral neck, which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. The epiphyseal growth plate (green overlay) is widened compared to the normal left side (arrows).

A Klein line (dashed line) drawn on the AP view along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck should intersect the epiphysis, but instead abnormally passes along its lateral edge. There is also a break in continuity of an S-shaped curve (S sign; red line) that can normally (blue line) be drawn along the posteroinferior cortex of the femoral head and neck on the frog-leg view.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither swelling nor erythema would not be expected with SCFE.

D) INCORRECT:

SCFE leads to a diminished range of motion at the hip. Thigh atrophy may be present.

E) INCORRECT:

A palpable mass over the hip joint would not be expected with SCFE.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy reports a 6-week history of progressively severe left-knee pain and difficulty walking. This is the first time he has ever experienced these symptoms. He reports no trauma, fevers, or infection.
On physical examination, he has overweight for his age and height (97th percentile for weight). He has full, pain-free range of motion of his left ankle and knee. Neither joint exhibits effusions or tenderness to palpation.
Examination of his left hip reveals limited internal and external rotation when the hip is passively flexed to 90 degrees. He is able to bear some weight on the left lower extremity, but he has an antalgic gait.
Which one of the following radiographic findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Erosive changes at the pubic symphysis
Widening of the proximal femoral epiphysis and a lower height of the femoral head relative to the contralateral hip
Erosion of the proximal femur with gas in the hip joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteitis pubis, an inflammatory condition of the pubic symphysis, may occur after a trauma or an overuse injury. Radiographic findings may not be evident early in the disease process, but after several weeks may reveal joint irregularity, sclerosis, and erosive changes at the pubic symphysis.

B) CORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) tends to occur between the ages of 10 and 16 years and is the most common hip disorder of adolescence. Risk factors include male sex, obesity, and Black or Pacific Islander ethnicity. SCFE often manifests with vaguely localized symptoms in the hip, groin, or knee. Therefore, hip pathology needs to be considered in a child or adolescent who reports knee pain.

Anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs of both hips are appropriate when a diagnosis of SCFE is suspected. Radiographic findings of SCFE on anteroposterior views can include widening and/or irregularity of the epiphyseal line and lower height of the femoral head relative to the contralateral side.

Advanced stages of SCFE are usually obvious on anteroposterior hip radiographs, but earlier stages may be subtle and appear only as a slight widening of the epiphysis relative to the contralateral side.

Key learning point: A hip radiograph that shows widening and/or irregularity of the epiphyseal line and lower height of the femoral head relative to the contralateral side suggests a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of gas in the hip joint is a concern for a septic joint and a surgical emergency; however, this patient has no other symptoms consistent with infection, such as fever or severe acute hip pain with movement.

D) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease most commonly affects boys aged 4 to 10 years. The condition is caused by a lack of blood supply to the femoral neck, leading to avascular necrosis. Radiographic studies show sclerosis of the femoral head in classic cases.

E) INCORRECT:

Hip apophysitis, an inflammation of the growth plate, may occur at any of the open growth plates of the hip and pelvis. The condition usually results from an overuse injury. At the site of the injury, radiographs show an open growth plate, which may be minimally widened, but most often no obvious abnormality is evident.

Transient synovitis, a diagnosis of exclusion, most commonly affects boys aged 3 to 8 years. Radiographs and laboratory test results are normal with this condition, and children usually improve rapidly within a few days of symptom onset.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents with insidious onset of left-knee pain, left-thigh pain, and a limp. She cannot recall any specific injury, illnesses, fever, or weight loss.
She appears well and is afebrile. Her left knee appears normal. She has hip pain on a log roll test; on passive hip flexion, the left hip rotates externally. Internal rotation of the hip is limited and painful.
A radiograph of the hip is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Administer an ultrasound-guided injection of betamethasone into the hip joint
Fit with crutches for non-weight-bearing ambulation, and refer urgently to an orthopedic surgeon
Prescribe scheduled ibuprofen for one week, and ask the patient to return if symptoms fail to improve
Obtain a complete blood count, C-reactive protein level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and initiate empiric antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral to physical therapy is appropriate for patients with hip pain related to muscle weakness or diminished flexibility.

B) INCORRECT:

Administering a glucocorticoid injection into the hip of a patient with pain of unknown etiology is inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) typically affects pre- or early adolescents, resulting in displacement of the femoral head from the femoral neck. Anterior-posterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs show the slip. The problem typically manifests with a limp in patients who are afebrile. They externally rotate and flex the hip for comfort and have pain with passive internal hip rotation. Referred obturator nerve pain can cause thigh or knee pain as the presenting complaint. Obesity is a significant risk factor.

The treatment for SCFE is surgical repair. Urgent referral to an orthopedic surgeon is necessary to prevent further slip or femoral-head avascular necrosis. The child should be non-weight-bearing (and thus fitted for crutches) until seen by an orthopedic surgeon. About 20% to 30% of cases also have a contralateral slip, so these children should be followed closely.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of hip pain in an afebrile school-age child who had no inciting injury or illness and who has limitation and pain on internal hip rotation is slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Scheduled ibuprofen is appropriate for transient synovitis, a self-limiting condition most often affecting 3- to 8-year-olds with a recent history of upper respiratory infection.

E) INCORRECT:

A painful hip, fever, and ill appearance warrant laboratory evaluation for septic arthritis and initiation of intravenous antibiotics. This child is afebrile and appears well.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 13-year-old right-handed baseball pitcher reports right upper-arm pain that developed about 4 weeks after he increased his practice and game play. He has played in several weekend tournaments lately, pitching up to two games per day.
His pain, localized to the proximal upper arm, aches at rest and worsens with any motion. It has improved in the past week following a rest from baseball.
His shoulder has a normal range of motion without pain; however, any manual muscle testing of shoulder strength causes pain in the proximal upper arm. He has point tenderness over the proximal upper arm, about 2 cm inferior to the acromion. There is no swelling or instability of the shoulder.
A plain-film radiograph of the right shoulder reveals slight widening of the proximal humeral physis compared with the left humerus.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An acromioclavicular (AC) sprain typically has an acute mechanism of injury and manifests as pain over the AC joint on adduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Humerus fractures rarely occur from stress and are much less common than proximal humeral epiphysiolysis in adolescents.

C) INCORRECT:

Multidirectional instability is indicated by positive testing, such as sulcus sign and apprehension testing, and by laxity detected on shoulder stressing.

D) CORRECT:

Repetitive force to any growth plate can cause a physeal fracture or injury. During early adolescence, the ligaments and other soft tissues are stronger than the bone, which results in more force being transmitted to bony structures, usually the physes. With enough repeated force, the affected physis becomes painful and eventually limits what the patient can comfortably do. On radiographs, widening of the physis is a clue to the diagnosis. Certain sports and positions (e.g., baseball pitcher) confer particularly high risk for physeal injuries, but any athlete is at risk if enough force is placed on a physis repeatedly. In this case, the patient threw enough pitches and other throws to cause a stress injury or fracture at the proximal humeral physis.

Key learning point: In a 13-year-old baseball pitcher, gradual onset of upper-arm pain from throwing, and radiographic evidence of widening of the proximal humeral physis, are most consistent with a diagnosis of proximal humeral epiphysiolysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Rotator cuff strains are uncommon in adolescents and typically cause pain with forward flexion and abduction.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy with a BMI above the 99th percentile for age reports pain in his left knee and left thigh. His mother first noticed him limping a month ago and attributed his pain to a recent rapid growth spurt. She scheduled today’s appointment when the pain did not resolve. The patient does not recall any specific injury and has otherwise been feeling well without recent illness.
His vital signs are normal. On examination, he has an antalgic gait and exhibits obligatory external rotation with passive hip flexion.
What is the most important next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of leukocyte count and C-reactive protein level

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is concerning for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), the most common hip disorder in adolescents.

SCFE occurs when the open physis (growth plate) allows for a posterior and inferior shift of the proximal femoral epiphysis on the metaphysis. Obesity (BMI >90th percentile) is the single greatest risk factor. The typical age of presentation is 8 to 15 years, but SCFE can also occur in older adolescents, especially if pubertal growth is later. In this case, the mother’s description of a recent growth spurt suggests that the patient is still in puberty with open growth plates.

Pain is the most common presenting symptom of SCFE and can occur in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Approximately 15% to 25% of affected patients present with knee pain, which leads to frequent misdiagnosis. Physical examination often reveals antalgic gait and limited internal rotation of the hip. Early recognition is important, as SCFE can be progressive.

Hip radiographs are required in the evaluation for SCFE and should be obtained for patients who have new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Once SCFE is diagnosed, patients should be referred to an orthopedic surgeon to determine appropriate treatment.

Key learning point: When an afebrile adolescent with obesity presents with new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee, hip radiographs should be obtained to assess for slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis and hips (A: frog leg lateral view; B: AP view)

The right femoral epiphysis (yellow overlay) is displaced posteriorly and rotated medially on the femoral neck, which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. The epiphyseal growth plate (green overlay) is widened compared to the normal left side (arrows).

A Klein line (dashed line) drawn on the AP view along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck should intersect the epiphysis, but instead abnormally passes along its lateral edge. There is also a break in continuity of an S-shaped curve (S sign; red line) that can normally (blue line) be drawn along the posteroinferior cortex of the femoral head and neck on the frog-leg view.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographs of the knee would not allow for evaluation for SCFE.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI can show early signs of SCFE, including growth-plate widening or metaphyseal edema, and may be considered if radiographs are negative. However, it is not the best initial imaging study, given the time-sensitive nature of appropriate diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

If the patient had fever, obtaining a complete blood count with differential and inflammatory markers (such as C-reactive protein) would be important. However, in the present case, urgent radiography is most important.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of the hip would be indicated if the patient had signs of septic arthritis, such as fever or illness, and the pain was localized to the hip joint. However, in the present case, urgent radiography is most important.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the office because of left left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Developmental dysplasia of the left hip

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.

B) CORRECT:

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

D) INCORRECT:

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

E) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy with a BMI above the 99th percentile for age reports pain in his left knee and left thigh. His mother first noticed him limping a month ago and attributed his pain to a recent rapid growth spurt. She scheduled today’s appointment when the pain did not resolve. The patient does not recall any specific injury and has otherwise been feeling well without recent illness. His vital signs are normal. On examination, he has an antalgic gait and exhibits obligatory external rotation with passive hip flexion. What is the most important next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of leukocyte count and C-reactive protein level

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

SCFE occurs when the open physis (growth plate) allows for a posterior and inferior shift of the proximal femoral epiphysis on the metaphysis. The etiology is not fully understood, but risk factors include obesity, family history, and endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism). The typical age of presentation is 10 to 16 years, but SCFE can also occur in older adolescents, especially if pubertal growth is later. In this case, the mother’s description of a recent growth spurt suggests that the patient is still in puberty with open growth plates.

Pain is the most common presenting symptom of SCFE and can occur in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Approximately 15% to 25% of affected patients present with knee pain, which leads to frequent misdiagnosis. Physical examination often reveals antalgic gait and limited internal rotation of the hip. Early recognition is important, as SCFE can be progressive.

X-ray of the hip is required in the evaluation for SCFE and should be obtained for patients who have new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Once SCFE is diagnosed, patients should be referred to an orthopedic surgeon to determine appropriate treatment.

Key learning point: When an afebrile adolescent with obesity presents with new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee, hip radiographs should be obtained to assess for slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis and hips (A: frog leg lateral view; B: AP view)

The right femoral epiphysis (yellow overlay) is displaced posteriorly and rotated medially on the femoral neck, which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. The epiphyseal growth plate (green overlay) is widened compared to the normal left side (arrows).

A Klein line (dashed line) drawn on the AP view along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck should intersect the epiphysis, but instead abnormally passes along its lateral edge. There is also a break in continuity of an S-shaped curve (S sign; red line) that can normally (blue line) be drawn along the posteroinferior cortex of the femoral head and neck on the frog-leg view.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographs of the knee would not allow for evaluation for SCFE.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI can show early signs of SCFE, including growth-plate widening or metaphyseal edema, and may be considered if radiographs are negative. However, it is not the best initial imaging study, given the time-sensitive nature of appropriate diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

If the patient had fever, obtaining a complete blood count with differential and inflammatory markers (such as C-reactive protein) would be important. However, in the present case, urgent radiography is most important.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of the hip would be indicated if the patient had signs of septic arthritis, such as fever or illness, and the pain was localized to the hip joint. However, in the present case, urgent radiography is most important.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation is concerning for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), the most common hip disorder in adolescents.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a 2-month history of pain in his left hip. The pain started suddenly and has worsened over the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the thigh and is aggravated by movement. He had a fall while cycling around a month ago. His BMI is 31 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Flexing the hip causes external rotation and abduction. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management in orthopedics consists of protection, optimal loading, ice, compression, and elevation (POLICE principle), along with NSAIDs for analgesia. This patient has a stable SCFE because he can bear weight without crutches. Conservative management alone will not suffice because weight-bearing may lead to an unstable SCFE, which is associated with a high risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

B) INCORRECT:

The localization of pain and reduced range of motion indicates that this patient has a hip condition. A long cast alone is not useful to treat hip pathologies. A hip spica cast with a long leg cast may be used to immobilize the hip and prevent further slipping in patients with a stable SCFE. However, this treatment modality is associated with a higher rate of complications than the preferred treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Surgical pinning of the femoral head refers to the placement of 1–2 pins through the femoral neck into the epiphysis and is used to treat SCFE to prevent further slipping of the epiphysis and promote closure of the epiphyseal plate. Surgical pinning is indicated for both stable and unstable SCFE. Prior to surgery, patients should avoid weight-bearing.

D) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular injection of lidocaine is used to treat severe pain in the knee, hip, elbow, and shoulder joint, but it is not indicated to treat SCFE.

E) INCORRECT:

Proximal femoral osteotomy is used to surgically treat Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) in children > 8 years of age or those with advanced disease. LCPD manifests with hip pain and a decreased range of motion. However, LCPD most commonly affects children between the ages of 4 and 10 years, and the onset of symptoms is usually insidious, with hip pain gradually worsening over months. Additionally, the x-ray in LCPD is either unremarkable or shows a dense, proximal femoral epiphysis that has a thinned-out, irregular surface and subchondral lucencies (indicating subchondral fractures).
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a child

The left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.

This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.
questions.hint: This adolescent boy with obesity has left hip pain, a positive Drehmann sign (passive flexion causes external rotation and abduction), and x-ray findings (widening of the left hip joint, cranial displacement of the femoral neck in relation to the femoral head) suggestive of a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy presents with a two-week history of right hip and groin pain. He reports occasional referred pain to his right knee that worsens with walking. He recalls mild discomfort after jumping from a low height but no significant injury. His body mass index is at the 95th percentile. Examination reveals a noticeable limp, outward-pointing right foot when walking, and markedly limited passive internal rotation of the hip with intensified pain. Baseline laboratory results, including hemoglobin, and inflammatory markers, are within normal limits (see image).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis typically presents with acute onset, high fever, and elevated inflammatory markers, which are absent here. The patient's two-week history of pain, normal laboratory results, and specific mechanical findings suggest a structural issue rather than an infection. The absence of joint effusion or systemic illness further reduces the likelihood of septic arthritis.

B) CORRECT:

Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) manifests when the proximal femoral epiphysis displaces relative to the metaphysis due to a weakened physis, often during rapid growth in obese adolescents. This condition presents with gradual onset hip and groin pain, sometimes referred to the knee, and a limping gait with obligatory external rotation. Physical examination reveals markedly limited internal rotation of the hip, reflecting altered biomechanics from the slip. The normal laboratory results suggest a mechanical rather than inflammatory or infectious process, supporting the diagnosis of SCFE.

Key learning point: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is common in overweight adolescents and presents with hip pain, external rotation, and limited range of motion, often following minor trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease typically affects children aged 4 to 10 years, younger than the patient described. It is not commonly associated with obesity, unlike SCFE. Although both conditions can present with hip pain and limited internal rotation, the patient's age and body mass index are more consistent with SCFE.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis usually occurs in children aged 3 to 8 years and often follows a viral infection, which is not reported here. Transient synovitis is typically self-limited and lacks the pronounced mechanical findings seen in this patient.

questions.text: You are seeing a 13-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and worsens with walking. He reports falling during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not seek medical attention at that time and does not recall any immediate or persistent pain after the fall. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. He has a left-sided antalgic gait, and his left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited by pain. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Developmental dysplasia of the left hip.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

C) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

Key learning point: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis typically presents in adolescents with hip or knee pain, an antalgic gait, and an externally rotated, painful hip with limited internal rotation.

E) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.
questions.hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old boy with a BMI above the 99th percentile for age who presents with pain in his left knee and left thigh. His mother noticed him limping a month ago, which she initially attributed to a recent rapid growth spurt. She brought him to clinic because the pain has persisted. He does not recall any specific injury and reports no recent illness. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has an antalgic gait and demonstrates obligatory external rotation with passive hip flexion. Which one of the following is the most important next step in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of leukocyte count and C-reactive protein level.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the patient had fever, obtaining a complete blood count with differential and inflammatory markers (such as C-reactive protein) would be important. However, in the present case, urgent radiography is most important.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of the hip would be indicated if the patient had signs of septic arthritis, such as fever or illness, and the pain was localized to the hip joint. However, in case of SCFE, a different step is more important.

C) CORRECT:

SCFE occurs when the open physis (growth plate) allows for a posterior and inferior shift of the proximal femoral epiphysis on the metaphysis. The etiology is not fully understood, but risk factors include obesity, family history, and endocrine disorders (e.g., hypothyroidism). The typical age of presentation is 10 to 16 years, but SCFE can also occur in older adolescents, especially if pubertal growth is later. In this case, the mother’s description of a recent growth spurt suggests that the patient is still in puberty with open growth plates.

Pain is the most common presenting symptom of SCFE and can occur in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Approximately 15% to 25% of affected patients present with knee pain, which leads to frequent misdiagnosis. Physical examination often reveals antalgic gait and limited internal rotation of the hip. Early recognition is important, as SCFE can be progressive.

X-ray of the hip is required in the evaluation for SCFE and should be obtained for patients who have new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee. Once SCFE is diagnosed, patients should be referred to an orthopedic surgeon to determine appropriate treatment.

Key learning point: When an afebrile adolescent with obesity presents with new-onset limp and pain in the hip, groin, thigh, or knee, hip radiographs should be obtained to assess for slipped capital femoral epiphysis.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis and hips (A: frog leg lateral view; B: AP view)

The right femoral epiphysis (yellow overlay) is displaced posteriorly and rotated medially on the femoral neck, which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. The epiphyseal growth plate (green overlay) is widened compared to the normal left side (arrows).

A Klein line (dashed line) drawn on the AP view along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck should intersect the epiphysis, but instead abnormally passes along its lateral edge. There is also a break in continuity of an S-shaped curve (S sign; red line) that can normally (blue line) be drawn along the posteroinferior cortex of the femoral head and neck on the frog-leg view.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiographs of the knee would not allow for evaluation for SCFE.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI can show early signs of SCFE, including growth-plate widening or metaphyseal edema, and may be considered if radiographs are negative. However, it is not the best initial imaging study, given the time-sensitive nature of appropriate diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient’s presentation is concerning for slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE), the most common hip disorder in adolescents.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with a BMI at the 98th percentile for age and sex presents with a 2-week history of left groin discomfort and subtle limping. He reports the pain as intermittent and rates it 4/10, with no history of trauma. He is able to walk unassisted. On examination, he holds his left hip in slight external rotation while standing. Passive flexion of the left hip results in obligate external rotation and abduction. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Bilateral hip radiographs and non-weight-bearing status
Unilateral hip radiographs and activity modification
MRI of the left hip and orthopedic referral

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This presentation suggests stable slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) based on the obligate external rotation during hip flexion (Drehmann sign) and the patient's ability to ambulate. Bilateral hip radiographs are essential, as SCFE is bilateral in 20–40% of patients. Immediate non-weight-bearing status prevents progression to unstable SCFE, which carries higher risks of complications, including avascular necrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Unilateral imaging is insufficient, as slipped capital femoral epiphysis is bilateral in 20–40% of patients, particularly in younger patients. The contralateral hip must be evaluated to rule out bilateral involvement and assess for prophylactic fixation needs.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is not the initial imaging modality for suspected slipped capital femoral epiphysis. While orthopedic referral is appropriate, MRI would delay necessary treatment and is not indicated for typical presentations.

D) INCORRECT:

While analgesia should be provided to this patient, it does not address the underlying pathomechanism. Physical therapy may be used in the management of slipped capital femoral epiphysis, but only after interventional treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Even stable slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) requires urgent orthopedic intervention to prevent progression to unstable SCFE. Observation would risk complications, including avascular necrosis.
